subject: -tion and friends vs. -en and -on
msgSnippet: I’m trying to assemble a Quikscript dictionary. To help me not screw up, I’m trying to write rules in Python code that I can use to check and make sure
messageBody:
I’m trying to assemble a Quikscript dictionary. To help me not screw up, I’m trying to write rules in Python code that I can use to check and make sure that I’m not misspelling dictionary entries.

One of the sticking points that I have is that oftentimes Read will make the Quikscript spelling dependent on the Orthodox spelling for one reason for another. The rules around ·ax and ·exam follow this; you’re supposed to use ·ax for ·key·see _only_ when Orthodox uses an X. I never liked this rule.

I think I’m getting a similar rationale for the ·utter-or-not rules for -tion and friends (no ·utter) vs. -en and -on (·utter-before-·no). Is the only way to tell whether an ·utter belongs is to look at the spelling in Orthodox, or is there a aural distinction that Read’s conveying that my California-tuned ears are deaf to?

(As an aside, I’d _love_ to be convinced that ·ax and ·exam are actually labor-saving devices. They seem wholly unnecessary, as there’s still that pesky penlift in both.)
